2. Brief Description
• Appearance: Lily of the Valley is a dainty, petite herbaceous perennial that grows from a slender running rhizome (underground root system)1.... The plant typically features two or three basal leaves that grow up to 30 cm long1. It produces a leafless stem bearing a one-sided cluster (raceme) of nodding, white, bell-shaped flowers that are highly aromatic1. Though it seldom forms, the plant can also produce a red berry as fruit1.
• Habitat and Common Locations: It is a popular ornamental perennial grown in gardens and yards35. Because of its beautiful and fragrant blooms, it is also very commonly brought indoors in cut flower arrangements and bouquets

toxins.name: Cardiac glycosides, specifically identified as convallarin, convallamarin, and convallatoxin
toxins.description:
in cats: These toxic sugars directly target the heart by inhibiting the Na
+
/K
+
-ATPase pump23. This inhibition causes an increase in intracellular sodium, which subsequently triggers an increase in intracellular calcium3. This cellular disruption significantly alters electrical conduction and how the cardiac muscle contracts, leading to profound cardiovascular depression, severe cardiac arrhythmias, a sudden drop in heart rate (bradycardia), and potentially seizures2....
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes: The plant contains roughly 38 different cardiac glycosides, making it powerfully toxic despite its dainty appearance46. These toxins are heavily concentrated throughout all parts of the plant (including the bulb, roots, rhizomes, stems, leaves, and flowers) and will even leach into the water of a vase holding the cut flowers

toxins.name: Irritant saponins
toxins.description:
in cats: Working alongside the cardiac glycosides, saponins act as severe gastrointestinal irritants1.... When a cat ingests the plant, these compounds trigger significant gastrointestinal upset, causing severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea (which may sometimes contain blood)1....
4. Notes on
toxins.concentration_notes:
Like the cardiac glycosides, these irritant saponins are distributed throughout the entire plant17.
(Note: While Lily of the Valley is highly poisonous and can disrupt normal heart activity and the gastrointestinal tract, the sources emphasize that it does not cause the acute, fatal kidney failure associated with "true lilies" of the Lilium and Hemerocallis families46.)

symptoms.name: Vomiting, diarrhea (which may contain blood), abdominal pain/discomfort, and trembling
symptoms.onset: Variable latent period depending on the dose;
symptoms.notes:
These symptoms are primarily triggered by the irritant saponins found throughout the plant12. The severe irritation of the gastrointestinal tract often precedes more dangerous systemic cardiovascular issues1.
2. Cardiovascular Depression and Arrhythmias

symptoms.name: Bradycardia (a sudden, significant decrease in heart rate) and severe cardiac arrhythmias (such as Atrioventricular or AV block)
symptoms.onset: Variable latent period depending on the dose;
symptoms.notes:
This is the most dangerous consequence of Lily of the Valley toxicity and is caused by the plant's cardiac glycosides2.... These toxins alter how the cardiac muscle contracts and disrupt electrical conduction57. In acute cases, this can also lead to hyperkalemia (dangerously high potassium levels in the blood), which can quickly result in death if left untreated12.
3. Neurological Abnormalities

symptoms.name: Seizures and tremors
symptoms.onset: Variable; usually develops as the cardiovascular depression worsens
symptoms.notes:
Seizures and trembling are secondary clinical signs that manifest as the toxins profoundly depress the cardiovascular system and disrupt cellular functions15.
(Note: While these symptoms are highly dangerous and potentially fatal, veterinary sources emphasize that Lily of the Valley does not cause the acute kidney failure associated with "true lilies"18.)

treatments.name: Gastrointestinal Decontamination
treatments.description: If the cat is asymptomatic and the ingestion is recent, the veterinarian will induce vomiting (emesis) or pump the stomach (gastric lavage) to remove the plant material. This is followed by administering a dose of activated charcoal with a cathartic to bind any remaining toxins in the gut.
treatments.notes:
Because these specific toxins can recirculate through the liver and intestines (enterohepatic recirculation), the vet will typically administer repeated doses of activated charcoal (without a cathartic) every 6 to 8 hours for a total of 3 doses12.
2. Antidote Administration (Digoxin-specific Antibody Fragments)

treatments.name: Administration of Digoxin-specific antibody fragments (Fab)
treatments.description: The veterinarian administers a specific antidote that is structurally designed to reverse digoxin toxicity, which cross-reacts and works effectively against the plant-based cardiac glycosides found in Lily of the Valley2.
treatments.notes:
While highly effective, this antidote may not always be readily available. If access to the antidote is unavailable, the veterinarian will rely heavily on the pharmacological treatments listed below to manage the symptoms2.
3. Pharmacological Cardiac Control (Antiarrhythmics)

treatments.name: Heart Rate and Arrhythmia Correction (Atropine, Lidocaine, Phenytoin)
treatments.description: The vet will use specific medications to stabilize the cat's heart. Atropine or glycopyrrolate is administered to correct bradycardia (a dangerously slow heart rate), while antiarrhythmic drugs like lidocaine or phenytoin are used to manage other heart rhythm abnormalities and conduction defects12.
treatments.notes:
During this treatment, the cat will require continuous, intensive electrocardiographic (ECG) monitoring to track the heart's electrical activity and adjust medications as needed1.
4. IV Fluid Therapy and Severe Electrolyte Management

treatments.name: Intravenous (IV) Fluid Therapy and Hyperkalemia Treatment
treatments.description: The cat is given IV fluids to provide hemodynamic support and manage dehydration from vomiting or diarrhea. Concurrently, the vet will monitor serum potassium levels, as acute poisoning can cause hyperkalemia (dangerously high potassium levels in the blood)12.
treatments.notes: Mild hyperkalemia may be resolved with IV fluids alone. However, if the hyperkalemia becomes severe (greater than 7.5–9 mEq/L), the veterinarian will need to treat it aggressively using sodium bicarbonate or a combination of dextrose and insulin therapy
